t: Isaiah 10
Woe*pn to those enacting crooked statutes and*ln writing oppressive laws
to*ln keep the poor from getting a fair trial and*ln to deprive the needy among my people of justice, so*ln that widows can be their spoil and*ln they can plunder the fatherless.
What*ln will you do on the day of punishment when*ln devastation comes from far away? Who*ln will you run to for help? Where*ln will you leave your wealth?
There*ln will be nothing to do except*ln crouch among the prisoners or*ln fall among the slain. In*ln all this, his anger has not turned away, and*ln his hand is still raised to strike.
Assyria, the Instrument of Wrath
Woe*pn to Assyria, the rod of my anger — the*ln staff in their hands is my wrath.
I*ln will send him against a godless nation; I*ln will command him to go against*ln a people destined for my rage, to*ln take spoils, to plunder, and*ln to trample them down like clay in the streets.
But*ln this is not what he intends; this*ln is not what he plans. It*ln is his intent to destroy and*ln to cut off many nations.
For*ln he says, “Aren’t*ln all my commanders kings?
Isn’t*ln Calno like Carchemish? Isn’t*ln Hamath like Arpad? Isn’t*ln Samaria like Damascus?
As*ln my hand seized the kingdoms of worthless images, kingdoms*ln whose idols exceeded those of Jerusalem and Samaria,
and*ln as I did to Samaria and its worthless images will*ln I not also do to Jerusalem and its idols?”
Judgment on Assyria
But*p when the Lord finishes all his work against Mount Zion and Jerusalem, he will say, “I will punish the king of Assyria for his arrogant acts and the proud look in his eyes.”

For he said: I*pn have done this by my own strength and*ln wisdom, for I am clever. I*ln abolished the borders of nations and*ln plundered their treasures; like*ln a mighty warrior, I subjugated the inhabitants.

My*ln hand has reached out, as if into a nest, to*ln seize the wealth of the nations. Like*ln one gathering abandoned eggs, I*ln gathered the whole earth. No*ln wing fluttered; no*ln beak opened or chirped.

Does*pn an ax exalt itself above*ln the one who chops with it? Does*ln a saw magnify itself above*ln the one who saws with it? It*ln would be like a rod waving the ones who lift it! It*ln would be like a staff lifting the one who isn’t wood!
Therefore*ln the Lord God*s of Armies will*ln inflict an emaciating disease on*ln the well-fed of Assyria, and*ln he will kindle a burning fire under*ln its glory.
Israel’s*ln Light will become a fire, and*ln its Holy One, a flame. In*ln one day it will burn and consume Assyria’s thorns and thistles.
He*ln will completely destroy the*ln glory of its forests and orchards as*ln a sickness consumes a person.
The*ln remaining trees of its forest will*ln be so few in number that*ln a child could count them.
The Remnant Will Return
On*p that day the remnant of Israel and the survivors of the house of Jacob will no longer depend on the one who struck them, but they will faithfully depend on the Lord,*s the Holy One of Israel.
The*pn remnant will return, the remnant of Jacob, to*ln the Mighty God.
Israel,*ln even if your people were as numerous as*ln the sand of the sea, only*ln a remnant of them will return. Destruction*ln has been decreed; justice*ln overflows.
For*ln throughout the land the*ln Lord God*s of Armies is*ln carrying out a destruction that was decreed.
Therefore,*p the Lord God*s of Armies says this: “My people who dwell in Zion, do not fear Assyria, though they strike you with a rod and raise their staff over you as the Egyptians did.
In just a little while my wrath will be spent and my anger will turn to their destruction.”
And the Lord*s of Armies will brandish a whip against him as he did when he struck Midian at the rock of Oreb; and he will raise his staff over the sea as he did in Egypt.
God Will Judge Assyria
On*pn that day his*ln burden will fall from your shoulders, and*ln his yoke from your neck. The*ln yoke will be broken because your neck will be too large.
Assyria*ln has come to Aiath and*ln has gone through Migron, storing*ln their equipment at Michmash.
They*ln crossed over at the ford, saying, “We*ln will spend the night at Geba.” The*ln people of Ramah are trembling; those*ln at Gibeah of Saul have fled.
Cry*ln aloud, daughter of Gallim! Listen,*ln Laishah! Anathoth*ln is miserable.
Madmenah*ln has fled. The*ln inhabitants of Gebim have sought refuge.
Today*ln the Assyrians will stand at Nob, shaking*ln their fists at the mountain of Daughter Zion, the*ln hill of Jerusalem.
Look,*ln the Lord God*s of Armies will*ln chop off the branches with terrifying power, and*ln the tall trees will be cut down, the*ln high trees felled.
He*ln is clearing the thickets of the forest with an ax, and*ln Lebanon with its majesty will fall.
